existing_custody_order.reasoning: The complaint expressly pleads an existing custody order entered by this Court on May 15, 2019 awarding joint legal custody and equal physical custody on a one-week-on/one-week-off schedule (see ¶¶1.4, 3.1).

specific_modification_sought.reasoning: The complaint specifically requests a change from the existing 50/50 alternating-week physical custody to primary physical custody with Plaintiff, a revised parenting-time schedule tailored to Defendant’s medical limitations (including reduced-duration visits, supervised visits, out-of-home visits), temporary pendente lite modification to primary custody if needed, and orders requiring medical documentation and evaluations (see ¶2.1, ¶5.2, ¶8(b)-(e)).

material_substantial_change.reasoning: The complaint alleges a concrete, post-judgment change: since mid-2024 Defendant was diagnosed with a progressive neurological condition causing mobility impairment, increased falls, need for assistance with transfers, and treating-physician recommendations limiting unsupervised contact in certain situations; it also alleges the child has been required to assist Defendant and has expressed fear (see ¶3.3–3.6, ¶4.1). Those facts are pleaded as a material and substantial change not contemplated by the 2019 order.

best_interests_of_child.reasoning: The complaint alleges why the requested modification serves the child’s best interests: increased safety risks from Defendant’s falls and limitations, inappropriate caregiver role of the 12‑year‑old, preservation of stability/routine with primary placement with Plaintiff, and supporting medical recommendations—tied directly to the requested custody and parenting-time changes (see ¶5.1(a)–(d), ¶5.2, ¶8(b)-(e)).
